Talk of aurora is in the air.  Our earlier story today by Elizabeth Howell
alerted you to the possibility of northern lights. Well, it's showtime!  As of
9:30 p.m. Central Daylight Time, the aurora has been active low in the
northern sky. (...)Read the rest of Clear Skies Tonight? Go Out and See the
Aurora (371 […]

articles.summary:
CAPE CANAVERAL Fla. (Reuters) - A rare double burst of magnetically charged
solar storms will hit Earth Thursday night and Friday, raising concerns that
GPS signals, radio communications and power transmissions could be disrupted,
officials said on Thursday.
articles.title: Double solar storms headed to Earth raise disruption concerns (reuters)

disease and to seek treatment after he infected eight people in four years.

articles.title: HIV-Positive Man Ordered to Stop Virus by Seattle Court (bioethicscom)

articles.summary:
Do you see it? The green slime at the western end of Lake Erie in the
satellite image above? That could be the source of the toxins  that have
caused the city of Toledo, Ohio to impose a drinking water ban affecting
500,000 people. The ban continued today, as further testing revealed evidence
of the toxin microcystin in a drinking water plant. Microcystin is produced by
blooms of cyanobacteria, also known as blue-green algae. In the image from
NASA's Terra satellite above, a widespread
articles.title: Holy Toledo! This Nasty Lake Erie Algae Bloom is the Likely Source of the Toxin Causing Your Drinking Water Woes (Discover Magazine)

articles.summary:
There are many ways to explain the reasons for space exploration: the
technological spin-offs, the science-education value, the commercial potential
of space, the pragmatic lessons back home in everything from space-weather
forecasting to mineral exploration. I've seen plenty of evidence that all
these things are true, yet they dance around the most essential and least
tangible motivation. We explore because it is what living things do. Movement
and the acquisition of knowledge are integral t
articles.title: Why We Explore: A Comet Tale Told in Four Pictures (Discover Magazine)
